biblStruct.note: In this article, Bergis Jules's discusses how digital Blackness has helped to define its impact on the culture, as it helps audiences "understand activism in this moment. [as well as] cultural expression, and surveillance of people of color online."

hyphenation.p: Except where normalization disrupts the formatting of the digital surrogate when rendered online, all end-of-line hyphenation in the original source material has been reformed. The choice element has been used to enclose orig and reg elements giving the original hyphenation and regularized version, respectively.

normalization.p: All obvious spelling and typographical errors in the original source material is corrected. The choice element has been used to enclose sic and corr elements giving the original error and correction, respectively.
Whenever necessary, spacing between words and following punctuation has been regularized to zero spaces; spacing between words has been regularized to one space.

Instances of African American Vernacular English have purposefully NOT been adjusted to comply with American English language practices. African American Vernacular English is wholly valid in its form, features, and creativity, despite the dominance and presumed correctness of American English.

editorialDecl.p: To represent changes and/or corrections made by the original source authors BEFORE the encoding process, encoders use add, del, and subst.
Encoding includes the use of supplied to provide clarification and supporting content, including out-links to relevant digital content and citations of Black and Black-centric academic research.

samplingDecl.p: Use as needed to explain when and why only portions or selections of the original source material are sampled.

projectDesc.p: This project seeks to identify, collect, preserve, and analyze FREEDOM discourse, as constituted and argued by Black users online. Directed by Dr. Jessica H. Lu, this project is currently being advanced by several undergraduate students at the University of Maryland, College Park: Sophia Crooks, Kayla Graham, Kaanita Iyer, Ariana Lawson, Alice Liu, and Courtney Richardson.

person.note: Shawn Carter, who also goes by Jay-Z is an African American rapper, entrepreneur, songwriter, and record producer. He is know as one of the most acclaimed rappers of all time.
